Situation1: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story:
I glance at my phone, the notification from the synagogue group chat lighting up the screen: “We need one more for minyan—can anyone come now?” My heart tightens. The funeral prayer is for Mr. Goldstein, a man I’ve known since childhood. I know how important it is to have a full minyan for Kaddish, to honor the dead and comfort the living. My community expects me to be there, to uphold our traditions.

But at the same time, my laptop is open to the live stream of the candidate forum. The election is next week, and this is the only chance to hear the candidates answer questions about the new housing policy. As a citizen, I feel a responsibility to stay informed, to participate, to send in my questions and vote thoughtfully. My neighbors and friends count on me to be engaged, to help shape our city’s future.

I stare at the screen, torn. The weight of both roles presses on me—my community’s need for tradition and my civic duty to be present and informed. My hands tremble as I try to decide which expectation I must let down.
